author: By Matt Apuzzo, Selam Gebrekidan and Monika Pronczuk
title: Where Europe Went Wrong in Its Vaccine Rollout, and Why
description: While Washington went into business with the drug companies, Europe was more fiscally conservative and trusted the free market.
content: BRUSSELS — The calls began in December, as the United States prepared to administer its first batches of Covid-19 vaccine. Even then, it was clear that the European Union was a few weeks behind, and its leaders wanted to know what they could learn from their American counterparts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Seeking to move past criticism, N.C.A.A. debuts new workout area for women’s tournament.
description: The N.C.A.A. has debuted a new weight room for its women’s basketball tournament in an attempt to move past a firestorm of condemnation for disparities between that competition in Texas and the men’s tournament in Indiana.
content: The N.C.A.A. has debuted a new weight room for its women’s basketball tournament in an attempt to move past a firestorm of condemnation for disparities between that competition in Texas and the men’s tournament in Indiana.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich and Ben Dooley
title: Spectators From Overseas Are Barred From Tokyo Olympics
description: The move, announced Saturday, is a significant concession to the realities of the pandemic, even as organizers remain determined to hold the Games this summer.
content: TOKYO — Spectators from overseas will not be allowed to attend the Summer Olympics in Japan, organizers said on Saturday, making a major concession to the realities of Covid-19 even as they forged ahead with plans to hold the world’s largest sporting event.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich and Ben Dooley
title: Overseas spectators are barred from the Tokyo Olympics.
description: TOKYO — Spectators from overseas will not be allowed to attend the Summer Olympics in Japan, organizers said on Saturday, making a major concession to the realities of Covid-19 even as they forged ahead with plans to hold the world’s largest sporting event.
content: TOKYO — Spectators from overseas will not be allowed to attend the Summer Olympics in Japan, organizers said on Saturday, making a major concession to the realities of Covid-19 even as they forged ahead with plans to hold the world’s largest sporting event.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Spring Is Here!
description: Celebrate the season with our most popular recipes of the week.
content: It’s the first day of spring, so crack open a window, break out those transitional sweaters and get ready to cook with all the green vegetables your heart desires. Vibrant cooking appears to be top of mind for NYT Cooking readers, as Yasmin Fahr’s salmon and couscous salad with cucumber-feta dressing (above), Melissa Clark’s roasted asparagus with crispy leeks and capers and Kay Chun’s saag paneer were some of our most popular recipes this week. But if temperatures are still low where you are, you’ll find comfort in this popular one-pot pasta with ricotta and lemon from Ali Slagle or this cheesy baked polenta in tomato sauce from Yotam Ottolenghi.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: More Steals, No Shifts and Robot Umps: ‘Our Fans Want the Action’
description: Raul Ibanez, Michael Hill and Morgan Sword discuss the changes baseball is implementing in the minors in hopes of spicing up things in the majors.
content: Major League Baseball, it must be said, remains wildly popular. It has by far the longest schedule of any major sport — 162 games per season — yet averaged more than 28,000 fans per game in 2019, more than every other season between 1876 and 1993.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin, Kate Taylor, Dana Goldstein and Shawn Hubler
title: In a Boost to Reopening Schools, C.D.C. Says Students Can Be 3 Feet Apart
description: The previous recommendation of six feet of distancing was a major obstacle to bringing students back for in-person learning.
content: In a major policy revision intended to encourage more schools to welcome students back full time, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said on Friday that elementary school students and some middle and high school students could be spaced three feet apart in classrooms, as long as everyone was wearing a mask.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock
title: A former Malaysian prime minister engulfed by a huge corruption case admits an ‘accidental mistake’ in violating a Covid regulation.
description: Najib Razak said he did not register with a phone app, as required, after arriving at a restaurant in Kuala Lumpur. “I confess,” he wrote on his Facebook page. “I accept both criticism and insight.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang and Joy Dong
title: Hong Kong, Its Elections Upended, Reconsiders Its Dream of Democracy
description: The promise of universal suffrage has animated the city’s politics for decades. Beijing’s latest moves could finally extinguish that hope.
content: HONG KONG — From her first protest at age 12, Jackie Chen believed she could help bring democracy to Hong Kong. Each summer, she marched in demonstrations calling for universal suffrage. She eagerly cast her ballot in elections.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Here are today’s scheduled games and how to stream them live.
description: Looking for a livestream for March Madness? Here’s where to find it.
content: As in recent years, the men’s games will be broadcast on CBS, TBS, TNT and TruTV. The official way to stream the tournament is through the N.C.A.A.’s March Madness Live app, which requires logging in through a TV provider. (The Paramount+ app, formerly known as CBS All Access, will also carry games broadcast on CBS.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: There Is No Rung on the Ladder That Protects You From Hate
description: Asian-Americans are reeling from the killings in Georgia and a rising number of attacks nationwide. Could confronting racism bring solidarity across their class divides?
content: The Asian-American experience is a tale of contrast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Libman
title: Was 1925 Literary Modernism’s Most Important Year?
description: “Ulysses” and “The Waste Land” appeared in 1922. But three years later, masterworks by Virginia Woolf, F. Scott Fitzgerald, Ernest Hemingway and John Dos Passos gave the movement its signature forms — and influence.
content: “An illiterate, underbred book it seems to me: the book of a self-taught working man, & we all know how distressing they are, how egotistic, insistent, raw, striking & ultimately nauseating.” So goes Virginia Woolf’s well-known complaint about “Ulysses,” scribbled into her diary before she had finished reading it. Her disparagement is catnip to those many critics who like to view “Mrs. Dalloway” — that other uber-famous, if more lapidary, modernist novel that spans the course of a single day — as Woolf’s rejoinder to Joyce. More than that, though, it tells us something important about our literary history. Nineteen twenty-two, the year of “Ulysses,” may well be ground zero for the explosion of modernism in literature. But the resultant shock wave is better captured by another year: 1925, that of “Mrs. Dalloway” and several other works, all now in the spotlight in 2021, as they emerge from under copyright.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz and Alan Blinder
title: N.C.A.A.’s Fear of a Canceled Tournament Game Arrives
description: Virginia Commonwealth was bounced from the men’s basketball tournament after what its coach described as “multiple positive tests.”
content: INDIANAPOLIS — It was a Faustian bargain that college basketball made last autumn when it plowed ahead with a season into the headwinds of the coronavirus pandemic. There would be games, college sports administrators declared, because there needed to be a path to the N.C.A.A. men’s tournament, which the governing body could ill afford to have canceled for the second year in a row.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: How to Collect $1.4 Trillion in Unpaid Taxes
description: Wealthy Americans are concealing large amounts of income from the I.R.S. There is a straightforward corrective.
content: When the federal government started withholding income taxes from workers’ paychecks during World War II, the innovation was presented as a matter of fairness, a way to ensure that everyone paid. Irving Berlin wrote a song for the Treasury Department: “You see those bombers in the sky? Rockefeller helped to build them. So did I.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilary Sheinbaum
title: Wedding Makeup Artists Are Putting Safety First
description: Beauty professionals are back to work and implementing strategies to stay safe while on a different pandemic frontline.
content: Over the last year, many brides, grooms and wedding party members have acted as their own glam squads, while other couples continued to hire in-person makeup artists for their wedding events — albeit with pandemic safety plans in place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: What to Know About the Assault Lawsuits Against Deshaun Watson
description: Seven women have filed civil lawsuits in Texas accusing the quarterback of a pattern of coercive and lewd behavior.
content: Houston Texans quarterback Deshaun Watson is the subject of seven civil suits filed in mid-March which accuse him of sexual assault. He was not charged criminally. Here’s where the cases stand:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Gentili
title: What Republicans Could Learn From My Grandmother
description: The Equality Act would provide consistent safeguards for L.G.B.T.Q. people, without taking anything away from anyone else.
content: How can I convince someone that I deserve to exist as much as anyone else?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Arrests Shake Up a Soccer Scene in Serbia Ruled by Gangsters and ‘Gravediggers’
description: A reputed gangster and leader of an “ultras” fan group, who also reportedly had ties to the government, has been arrested following a series of gruesome murders connected to a Belgrade soccer stadium.
content: BELGRADE — Shortly after arresting a man suspected of leading a criminal gang last month in connection with a series of killings involving beheadings and torture, Serbian police officers raided what they believe was the band’s secret lair: a bunkerlike room in the bowels of a stadium used by Partizan Belgrade, a storied soccer team in the Serbian capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: How the Pandemic Changed Your Politics
description: Worry, anxiety, hope: Readers shared how they experienced a wild year in American life and politics.
content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your wrap-up of the week in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host. Sign up here to get this newsletter in your inbox every weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Old Pol, New Tricks
description: Biden’s got the buzz. Who’s smirking now?
content: WASHINGTON — Joe Biden never had a seat at the cool kids’ table at the Obama White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron DePasquale, Roni Caryn Rabin, Kate Taylor, Shawn Hubler and Dana Goldstein
title: Parents and school leaders celebrate new C.D.C. guidance lowering distance between students to 3 feet. Teachers aren’t on board yet.
description: The heads of two large teachers’ unions are waiting for further review of research on how the virus behaves in schools, especially those in cities or that are under-resourced.
content: Proponents of fully reopening schools got a major boost on Friday when the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention announced that elementary school students and some middle and high school students could be spaced three feet apart in classrooms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
description: Daniel Raymon returns with a panoply of perplexity.
content: PUNS AND ANAGRAMS — It took a little while for me to build the necessary momentum for this Panda puzzle, another worthy challenge from Daniel Raymon. The first four across clues are all pretty tricky in their own ways, and after missing on all of them, my eyes got drawn to more difficult stuff. I thought the simple anagrams felt scarce, but of course there were plenty, hiding in plain sight — I always recommend that people start with those to get a little traction, so there I go, ignoring my own advice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Trump’s Mar-a-Lago club partially closed after positive coronavirus tests.
description: The club is set to play host to events during the Republican National Committee spring retreat in Florida next month. It has been Mr. Trump’s post-presidency base of operations.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump’s private club in Palm Beach, Fla., was partially closed on Friday following some staff members testing positive for the coronavirus, two people familiar with the events confirmed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Imbler and Andrew Garn
title: The Perseverance of New York City’s Wildflowers
description: A park in Williamsburg awaits the miniature beauty of its spring blossoms.
content: In Williamsburg, on a seven-acre park by the East River, spring will soon unfurl in blue blossoms. Cornflowers are always the first to bloom in the pollinator meadow of Marsha P. Johnson State Park, a welcome sign to bees and people that things are beginning to thaw.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Return of Traffic Cops to Landmark Piazza Brings Unlikely Joy in Rome
description: While motorists in Rome are known for their chaotic driving, the return of police officers directing traffic at the intersection was greeted by many as a sign of normality at a difficult time.
content: ROME — If, as it’s said, all roads lead to Rome, then they intersect at Piazza Venezia, the downtown hub of the Italian capital, watched over by a traffic officer on a pedestal who choreographs  streamlined circulation out of automotive chaos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: Erdogan Pulls Turkey From European Treaty on Domestic Violence
description: The move is likely to please President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s conservative followers. He also removed the head of the central bank.
content: ISTANBUL — In two surprise midnight decrees, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has withdrawn Turkey from an international treaty on preventing violence against women and removed the head of the central bank, moves likely to please his followers but further estrange him from Western partners.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salman Masood
title: Pakistan’s prime minister tests positive for the coronavirus.
description: Imran Khan, a former cricket star, recently received his first dose of a vaccine, and officials said he was most likely infected beforehand.
content: ISLAMABAD — Prime Minister Imran Khan of Pakistan has tested positive for the coronavirus, officials said Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives and Amy Qin
title: In East Asia, Responses to the Georgia Attacks Were Lean on Outrage
description: Six of the eight victims were of Asian descent. But in China and South Korea, debate over the violence played out with far less intensity than it did in the United States.
content: HONG KONG — When six of the eight victims of this week’s shootings at Atlanta-area spas were confirmed to be of Asian descent, the news reopened wrenching debates in the United States about anti-Asian violence, bigotry and misogyny.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Barker, Mike Baker and Ali Watkins
title: In City After City, Police Mishandled Black Lives Matter Protests
description: Inquiries into law enforcement’s handling of the George Floyd protests last summer found insufficient training and militarized responses — a widespread failure in policing nationwide.
content: For many long weeks last summer, protesters in American cities faced off against their own police forces in what proved to be, for major law enforcement agencies across the country, a startling display of violence and disarray.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliana Kim, Sean Keenan and Richard Fausset
title: Protesters Gather in Atlanta to #StopAsianHate
description: The event in a park next to the State Capitol was billed as way for people to “come together to grieve, heal and support.”
content: ATLANTA — After a week of pain, fear and mourning, Georgia’s capital city hosted a downtown march and rally on Saturday to protest the killing of eight people, six of them women of Asian descent, by a gunman who targeted three Atlanta-area massage businesses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Mores
description: Julian Kwan makes a debut with panache.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Julian Kwan is a software test engineer in telecommunications who is new to the vocation of crossword construction; this is his fourth published grid, and his first with us. I like a Sunday debut, and this is a fun endeavor: The theme is clean and deceptively simple, embedded in zippy fill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: What the 2020s Need: Sex and Romance at the Movies
description: We’ll know we’re actually escaping stagnation when the cinema of desire returns.
content: A slight giddiness is overtaking prognosticators as the pandemic nears its end. Economics writers, normally a cautious bunch, are speculating about how a Biden boom might really be different — bigger, longer, its fruits more widely shared — than the limping recoveries we’ve seen recently. Tech and science watchers are talking about the 2020s as an age of breakthroughs, a long-awaited acceleration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Richard H. Driehaus, Champion of Classic Architecture, Dies at 78
description: A Chicago investor and philanthropist, he was an apostle of historic preservation and established an annual prize to celebrate traditional design.
content: Richard H. Driehaus, an avid investor who grew his grade-school coin collection into a fortune that he wielded to champion historic preservation and classical architecture, died on March 9 in a Chicago hospital. He was 78.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The International Herald Tribune
title: 1946: Dutch Workers Protest Franco Without Using His Name
description: After they were forbidden by Rotterdam’s mayor from mentioning Franco, dock workers used banners proclaiming “Down with …”
content: ROTTERDAM, March 19. — More than 3,500 Rotterdam dock workers demonstrated against Franco Spain today, but their banners merely proclaimed enigmatically: “Down with …”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky
title: Canadian Snowbirds Find Refuge in Their Mythical Miami
description: In this retirement community celebrating all things Florida, Quebec snowbirds hunkered down this winter to ride out the pandemic.
content: SAINT-AMBROISE, Quebec — In a retirement community north of Quebec City, 30-foot plastic palm trees overlook Miami, Orlando and Cocoa Avenues, cookie-cutter streets where residents glide by some days on snowshoes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham
title: Atlanta Suspect’s Fixation on Sex Is Familiar Thorn for Evangelicals
description: The man accused of killing eight people, including six women of Asian descent, blamed “sexual addiction,” a disputed term used in parts of evangelical culture.
content: When Brad Onishi heard that the man accused of a rampage at three Atlanta-area spas told detectives that he had carried out the attacks as a way to eliminate his own temptations, the claim sounded painfully familiar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Virginia Commonwealth was forced out of the N.C.A.A. tournament by the coronavirus.
description: Oregon will move on to the second round of the tournament.
content: The coronavirus pandemic disrupted the N.C.A.A.’s Division I men’s basketball tournament for the first time on Saturday, when a planned game between seventh-seeded Oregon and Virginia Commonwealth, a No. 10 seed, was declared a no-contest because of virus-related issues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Z. Klein
title: Rooting for Your Home Team in Person? Here’s What You Need to Know.
description: This spring, big-league games are luring fans to stadiums and arenas. Expect varying levels of mask-wearing, social distancing and pregame testing.
content: From strict testing, masking and physical-distancing protocols in New York and California, to a full 40,000-seat stadium with almost no coronavirus restrictions outside Dallas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley
title: Strong Earthquake Shakes Japan’s Northeast
description: The 7.2-magnitude quake, which could be felt hundreds of miles away in Tokyo, briefly prompted a tsunami warning.
content: A 7.2-magnitude earthquake shook northeastern Japan on Saturday evening, prompting a tsunami warning that was quickly lifted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris
title: How Crying on TikTok Sells Books
description: “BookTok” videos are starting to influence publishers and best-seller lists, and the verklempt readers behind them are just as surprised as everyone else.
content: “We Were Liars” came out in 2014, so when the book’s author, E. Lockhart, saw that it was back on the best-seller list last summer, she was delighted. And confused.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charanna Alexander
title: Love Letter: Healing in the Form of a Designer Dress
description: And: A basketball legend’s daughter says “I do”
content: The emotional upheaval of a serious illness can make it difficult to cope in all aspects of life. When Emilie Poplett, the writer of this week’s Modern Love essay, developed frightening symptoms — fever, weight loss, bruising — she turned to medical professionals and even unorthodox healers for an explanation. While enduring numerous tests and painful procedures, each one inconclusive, Ms. Poplett found solace and temporary healing by buying pre-owned luxury garments. Each purchase was a hopeful promise of a future where she would be well enough to wear them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: ‘Dear G.I.’: An Unlikely Friendship Built on Letters From a Foxhole
description: In 1966, a Massachusetts mother of three began writing to young men serving in Vietnam. One became her most steadfast pen pal, writing her 77 letters over seven years.
content: In 1966, Joan Hunter of Scituate, Mass., sat down with her husband and three children to watch a special news report about the Vietnam War.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: Progressive Christians Arise! Hallelujah!
description: With a churchgoing Democrat in the White House, faith becomes more complicated in America. Thank God.
content: Young and middle-aged Americans could be forgiven for thinking that Jesus was a social conservative who denounced gay people and harangued the poor to lift themselves up by the bootstraps, until he was crucified for demanding corporate tax cuts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: Lighting Up Later in Life
description: The number of older adults who use cannabis is on the rise, and some health experts are concerned.
content: For years, Harry B. Lebowitz spent the cocktail hour at his home in Delray Beach, Fla., sitting in his backyard overlooking a lake and smoking a joint while his partner relaxed with her vodka and club soda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Erdbrink, Marc Santora, Denise Grady and Rebecca Robbins
title: Denmark reports a death and a critical illness after 2 AstraZeneca vaccinations, prompting more reviews.
description: The country’s drug agency is investigating whether these were side effects.
content: Denmark reported on Saturday that two people had experienced brain hemorrhages after receiving the AstraZeneca Covid-19 vaccine, one of whom died. The Danish Medicines Agency said it was looking into whether the condition was a potential side effect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: Fact-Checking Claims on the Migrant Surge at the U.S.-Mexico Border
description: As migrants arrive at the southwestern border in increasing numbers, lawmakers and officials are misleading about border policies, migrants, the coronavirus and immigration flows.
content: With the number of migrants apprehended at the southwestern border expected to reach a two-decade high, Republicans are blaming President Biden for the surge, while Democrats argue that immigration system he inherited left him ill-prepared.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Zucchino and Fahim Abed
title: Risking Death, Hazara Students Pursue Education at Bombed Academies
description: A group of young Afghans studying for college entrance exams must risk suicide attacks by the Islamic State and the looming threat of a Taliban return.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — Two and a half years ago, a suicide bomber detonated an explosive vest during an algebra class at the Mawoud Academy tutoring center. At least 40 students, most from Afghanistan’s Hazara ethnic minority, died as they studied for college entrance exams.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Mixed Virus Data Has Some Experts Questioning Pace of N.Y.C. Reopening
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced this week that businesses like indoor fitness studios would be allowed to reopen.
content: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced recently that New York City would take several more steps toward normalcy: More people would soon be allowed in restaurants; an 11 p.m. curfew at businesses like movie theaters would end; and yoga classes, among other indoor fitness activities, would be allowed to restart.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: She’s 89. She Doesn’t Wear Glasses. And She’s a World-Class Sharpshooter.
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, March 20, 2021.
content: “All the household chores I used to do from a young age, like grinding the wheat by hand, milking the cows, cutting the grass.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Yuhas
title: Man Says He Lived in Philadelphia’s Veterans Stadium for Years
description: Several people corroborated parts of the account of Tom Garvey, a Vietnam veteran and former stadium employee who described his “secret apartment” in a recent book.
content: PHILADELPHIA — Like other Vietnam veterans in the 1970s, Tom Garvey chased one job after another, fending off memories. Unlike other veterans, he says he turned a concession stand in a major American stadium into a place to crash for three years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives and Elian Peltier
title: A Volcano Erupted in Iceland. Björk Was ‘Sooo Excited.’
description: No injuries were reported after the rare eruption near Reykjavik — only joy, on the part of the singer, volcanologists and other Icelanders.
content: A volcano erupted in Iceland on Friday, essentially turning the night sky into a real-life lava lamp.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Virus Cases Delay Effort to Bring Indoor Dance Back to New York
description: The Park Avenue Armory is postponing “Afterwardsness” after three members of the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane dance company tested positive for the coronavirus.
content: It was one of the most high-profile experiments to bring indoor live performance back to New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikolas Bowie
title: Do We Have to Pay Businesses to Obey the Law?
description: A motel owner in 1964 sued over being forced to accommodate Black patrons. Now agribusinesses are borrowing his argument to bar union organizers.
content: If the government was going to force Southern businesses to “serve Negroes,” then the government should have to pay the businesses for each Negro they allowed on their property.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Confronting Violence Against Asians, Biden Says That ‘We Cannot Be Complicit’
description: Vice President Kamala Harris joined the president in forcefully condemning the killings in Atlanta. “Racism is real in America, and it has always been,” she said.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris traveled on Friday to Atlanta to express grief for the victims of a mass shooting that left eight people dead, six of them women of Asian descent, describing the tragedy as part of an increase in racially motivated violence and pledging to take action against hate and discrimination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dorothy A. Brown
title: Your Home’s Value Is Based on Racism
description: Wherever they choose to buy, Black people are penalized by white preferences.
content: John, who is Black, and his wife, who is Japanese American, purchased a family home in a suburb of Atlanta in 2004.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By May Jeong
title: The Deep American Roots of the Atlanta Shootings
description: The victims lived at the nexus of race, gender and class.
content: Among the first things I did upon learning about the shootings at three massage parlors in the Atlanta area was to check in with a former massage parlor worker I met in 2019. At the time, I was reporting an article about a prostitution raid at a Florida massage parlor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Becker
title: I Don’t Want My Role Models Erased
description: This is how women who covered Vietnam were marginalized in the war’s history.
content: Vietnam, the 10-year American fiasco that foreshadowed the disastrous forever wars of today, was written into history as it happened. The war’s most famous chroniclers — David Halberstam, Neil Sheehan and Malcolm Browne — were young men, all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: After Being Scratched and Punched, Trump Wax Figure Is Removed
description: The figure at Louis Tussaud’s Palace of Wax in San Antonio was so badly battered that it required repairs.
content: When he was in office, President Donald J. Trump often complained that he felt battered and under assault, but that did not compare with the physical beating a wax statue of the former president recently endured at a Texas attraction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: My Tenant Won’t Pay, but Won’t Go. What Can I Do?
description: There are no easy options when it comes to collecting back rent these days, so landlords would be wise to seek compromises with tenants.
content: Q: My sister owns a single-family home in Queens Village with a tenant who stopped paying rent well over a year ago and refuses to move. At this point, my sister wants to sell the house — she can’t afford to keep paying the mortgage while a family lives there rent-free. But can she sell a house that’s occupied by a tenant who won’t pay? And for how much?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin J. Delaney
title: What Is Work Worth?
description: Big ideas for rethinking pay.
content: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in the news. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliana Kim, Corina Knoll and Campbell Robertson
title: ‘All I Can Think About Is Her’: Families Grieve for Victims of Atlanta Attacks
description: Among the eight people killed at Atlanta-area spas this week was a wife going for a massage with her husband, and immigrant mothers working long hours to support their children.
content: ATLANTA — From early in the morning until late at night, Hyun Jung Grant was at work. She was a single mother with life’s unyielding obligations: two sons who needed college tuition, the rent on the home they all shared, the relentless drumbeat of bills.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Dawn Staley, South Carolina’s respected coach, sharply criticizes N.C.A.A. leaders.
description: After it became clear that the women’s basketball tournament had been given inferior resources, Staley called on the leaders to “re-evaluate the value they place on women.”
content: Dawn Staley, one of the most admired coaches in women’s basketball, excoriated the N.C.A.A. on Friday for its approach to her sport and its national tournament — a 64-team event that the governing body of college sports acknowledged Friday had received inadequate resources compared with those available in the men’s competition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin
title: Louisiana House Race Sets Up a Democratic Showdown in New Orleans
description: The first competitive special congressional election of 2021 will unfold on Saturday, with two rival Democrats poised for a runoff to succeed the Biden adviser Cedric Richmond.
content: DONALDSONVILLE, La. — The first competitive special congressional election of the Biden era is most likely heading to a runoff next month, but the battle lines are already drawn ahead of the initial balloting on Saturday in the race to succeed former Representative Cedric L. Richmond of Louisiana.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Hot Off the Press
description: Emily Carroll delivers a toe-tapping Saturday diversion.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Who can begrudge any weekend puzzle that includes a reference to an anthem for the solver of weekend puzzles?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Bernstein
title: Here’s How Bored Rich People Are Spending Their Extra Cash
description: The value of collectibles — like coffee tables, whiskey, Air Jordans and Pokémon cards — has soared.
content: Rich people who shopped too much used to be called collectors. Now they — and those belonging merely to the aspirational class — are all investors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Adam Rasgon
title: Palestinian Hamlet Embodies Fight for the West Bank’s Future
description: Israel suspended a decision to annex a section of the territory last year, but its military still exerts tight control over Palestinians in the area.
content: HUMSA, West Bank — Until last November, Fadwa Abu Awad’s mornings followed a familiar rhythm: The 42-year-old Palestinian herder would rise at 4 a.m., pray, and milk her family’s sheep. Then she would add an enzyme to the pails of milk and stir them for hours to make a salty, rubbery, halloumi-like cheese.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: That Was Fast: Blowups With China and Russia in Biden’s First 60 Days
description: It may look like the bad old days of the Cold War, but today’s bitter superpower competition is about technology, cyberconflict and influence operations.
content: WASHINGTON — Sixty days into his administration, President Biden got a taste this week of what the next four years may look like: a new era of bitter superpower competition, marked by perhaps the worst relationship Washington has had with Russia since the fall of the Berlin Wall, and with China since it opened diplomatic relations with the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei and Christina Morales
title: Miami Beach to spring breakers: No more late-night partying.
description: Law enforcement began dispersing crowds and blocking roads after city officials imposed an evening curfew to curtail public safety and coronavirus concerns.
content: The city of Miami Beach, worried about big crowds filling the streets of South Beach and the threat of a resurgent coronavirus, moved up its curfew on Saturday in an effort to shut down late-night spring break partying it said had gotten out of control.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Biden and Harris Condemn Violence Against Asian-Americans
description: President Biden and Vice President Harris expressed grief for the victims of the mass shooting in Atlanta and outrage over increasing violence against Asian-Americans. Six of the victims were of Asian descent.
content: President Biden and Vice President Harris expressed grief for the victims of the mass shooting in Atlanta and outrage over increasing violence against Asian-Americans. Six of the victims were of Asian descent.

author: By The Associated Press
title: China Talks Were Challenging but ‘Candid,’ Blinken Says
description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and Jake Sullivan, the national security adviser, said Friday that they had raised contentious matters with their Chinese counterparts over two days.
content: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and Jake Sullivan, the national security adviser, said Friday that they had raised contentious matters with their Chinese counterparts over two days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Europe Begins Administering AstraZeneca Vaccines Again
description: On Friday, governments across Europe raced to restart use of AstraZeneca’s coronavirus vaccine after the announcement from the European Union’s top drug regulator on Thursday that the shots were safe and effective.
content: On Friday, governments across Europe raced to restart use of AstraZeneca’s coronavirus vaccine after the announcement from the European Union’s top drug regulator on Thursday that the shots were safe and effective.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Rally in Atlanta to #StopAsianHate
description: Protesters marched in Atlanta on Saturday to condemn anti-Asian violence. On Tuesday, a white gunman killed eight people, including six women of Asian descent, at three Atlanta-area spas.
content: Protesters marched in Atlanta on Saturday to condemn anti-Asian violence. On Tuesday, a white gunman killed eight people, including six women of Asian descent, at three Atlanta-area spas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Earthquake Rattles Japan’s Northeast
description: A 7.2-magnitude earthquake shook northeastern Japan late Saturday, and was felt hundreds of miles away in Tokyo. The earthquake prompted a tsunami warning that was quickly lifted.
content: A 7.2-magnitude earthquake shook northeastern Japan late Saturday, and was felt hundreds of miles away in Tokyo. The earthquake prompted a tsunami warning that was quickly lifted.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: March 20, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, March 20, 2021.
content: An article on Thursday about increasing homelessness in the United States referred incorrectly to data supplied by ChildTrends, a research organization based in Bethesda, Md. It was analyzed last month; renters and homeowners were not interviewed last month.
source.name: The New York Times

description: Readers discuss a Sunday Review article on how the pandemic has made the incredibly difficult even harder.
